facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1099-1101 of 1963 were filed.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment dated January 24, 1961 of the Madras High Court in R.C. No. 143 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment dated January 24, 1961 of the Madras High Court in R.C. No. 143 of 1956. K. Daphtary, Attorney-General, N. D. Karkhanis and R. Sachthey, for the appellant.

facts.text: The assessee-firm was the Managing Agents of Palani Andavar Mills Ltd., Udamalpet.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee-firm was the Managing Agents of Palani Andavar Mills Ltd., Udamalpet. It was originally constituted by a deed of partnership, dated June 1, 1934.

facts.text: Assessee-firm originally constituted by a deed of partnership dated June 1, 1934.

anchor.surface_text: It was originally constituted by a deed of partnership, dated June 1, 1934. The following 6 persons were the partners G. Venkataswami Naidu As. 2 G. T. Narayanaswamy Naidu As. 2

facts.text: Original partners: G. Venkataswami Naidu (2 as), G. T. Narayanaswamy Naidu (2 as), G. T. Krishnaswamy Naidu (2 as), M. A. Palaniappa Chettiar (5 as), R. Guruswamy Naidu (2 1/2 as), K. Venkatasubba Naidu (2 1/2 as).

anchor.surface_text: The following 6 persons were the partners G. Venkataswami Naidu As. 2 G. T. Narayanaswamy Naidu As. 2 G. T. Krishnaswamy Naidu As. 2 M. A. Palaniappa Chettiar As. 5 R. Guruswamy Naidu As. 2 1/2 K. Venkatasubba Naidu As. 21 By subsequent transactions the share of G. Venkataswami Naidu

facts.text: Share of G. Venkataswami Naidu transferred to his son Vidyasagar.

anchor.surface_text: By subsequent transactions the share of G. Venkataswami Naidu  1  19652S.C.R. 12. was transferred to his son Vidyasagar and the share of M. A. Palaniappa Chettiar was purchased by R. Guruswamy Naidu.

facts.text: Share of M. A. Palaniappa Chettiar purchased by R. Guruswamy Naidu, resulting in his share becoming 7 1/2 annas.

anchor.surface_text: was transferred to his son Vidyasagar and the share of M. A. Palaniappa Chettiar was purchased by R. Guruswamy Naidu. With the result that the 5th partner, G. Guruswamy, had 7 1/2 annas share in the partnership instead of 2 1/2 annas share which he held earlier.

facts.text: Guruswamy Naidu and Venkatasubba Naidu belonged to a Hindu undivided family and beneficial interest of their shares belonged to that family.

anchor.surface_text: Guruswamy Naidu and Venkatasubba Naidu, the 5th and 6th partners, belonged to a Hindu undivided family and the beneficial interest of their shares belonged to that family indeed, during the previous years the joint family was assessed in respect of the income pertaining to the said shares.

facts.text: Joint family was assessed in respect of the income pertaining to the said shares during previous years.

anchor.surface_text: indeed, during the previous years the joint family was assessed in respect of the income pertaining to the said shares. On August 24, 1950, the said Hindu undivided family was divided and a partition deed was executed between the members thereof.

facts.text: On August 24, 1950, the Hindu undivided family was divided and a partition deed executed.

anchor.surface_text: On August 24, 1950, the said Hindu undivided family was divided and a partition deed was executed between the members thereof. Under the deed the ten annas share held by the family was divided as follows

facts.text: Partition shares: R. Guruswamy Naidu (2 as), Rudrappa (minor son, 1 anna), Venkataramana (minor son, 1 anna), Subba Naidu (2 as), Venkatasubba Naidu (1-4 as), Rudrappa Naidu (1-4 as), Jagannatha Naidu (1-4 as).

anchor.surface_text: Under the deed the ten annas share held by the family was divided as follows R. Guruswamy Naidu As.2 Rudrappa  Minor son of No. 1  Anna 1 Venkataramana  Minor son of No. 1  Anna 1 Subba Naidu As. 2 Venkatasubba Naidu As. 1-4 Rudrappa Naidu As. 1-4 Jagannatha Naidu As. 1-4 After the said partition, on November 30, 1950, a new pertner-ship deed was executed between the partners of the assessee-firm.

facts.text: On November 30, 1950, a new partnership deed was executed between the partners of the assessee-firm.

anchor.surface_text: After the said partition, on November 30, 1950, a new pertner-ship deed was executed between the partners of the assessee-firm. Under the said partnership deed the following shares were allotted to each of the partners

facts.text: Shares in new partnership deed: R. Guruswamy Naidu (7 1/2 as), R. Venkatasubba Naidu (2 1/2 as), G. T. Narayanaswamy Naidu (2 as), G. T. Krishnaswamy Naidu (2 as), Vidyasagar (2 as).

anchor.surface_text: Under the said partnership deed the following shares were allotted to each of the partners R. Guruswamy Naidu As. 71 R. Venkatasubba Naidu As. 21 G. T. Narayanaswamy Naidu As. 2 G. T. Krishnaswamy Naidu As. 2 Vidyasagar As. 2 The point to be numbericed is that the beneficial interest in 10 annas share originally belonged to the Hindu undivided family

facts.text: Assessee-firm presented the deed of partnership dated November 30, 1950, to ITO for registration for assessment years 1952-53, 1953-54, 1954-55 and was registered under s. 26A.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee- firm presented the deed of partnership, dated November 30, 1950, before the Income-tax Officer for registration for the assessment years 1952-53, 1953-54 and 1954-55 and was duly registered under s. 26A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, here- inafter called the Act.

facts.text: Guruswamy Naidu and Venkatasubba Naidu assessed as partners on their respective shares as per partnership deed.

anchor.surface_text: In due companyrse Guruswamy Naidu and Venkatasubba Naidu were assessed as partners of the assessee-firm on their respective shares as shown in the partnership deed. But the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, in respect of two of the assessments made on them, accepted their companytention

facts.text: ITAT accepted contention of Guruswamy Naidu and Venkatasubba Naidu that they were liable only on shares per partition deed in two assessments.

anchor.surface_text: But the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, in respect of two of the assessments made on them, accepted their companytention and held that they were liable only to pay tax in respect of the shares shown in the partition deed.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax under s. 33B cancelled registration of partnership on ground that deed did not show correct shares.

anchor.surface_text: After the decision of the Tribunal, the Commissioner of Income-tax acting under s. 33B of the Act cancelled the registration of the partnership on the ground that the partnership deed did number show the companyrect shares of the partners in the partnership.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal confirmed Commissioner's order cancelling registration for 3 years.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Appellate Tribunal companyfirmed the order of the Commissioner in respect of the 3 assessment years. At the instance of the assessee- firm the following questions of law were referred to the High Court.

facts.text: Madras High Court held partnership genuine, answered first question in negative, second in affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the Madras High Court, which heard the reference, came to the companyclusion that the partnership was a genuine one, that the partition in the joint Hindu family allotting specific shares to the members of the family might have affected the accountability of the two partners of the firm to the other members of the family, but qua the partnership their relationship with the other partners had number in any way been affected and, therefore, the Tribunal went wrong in holding that the registration of the said partnership was rightly refused.

facts.text: Revenue contended that partnership deed did not specify correct shares of Guruswamy Naidu (entitled to 2 annas per partition but shown 7 1/2) and Venkatasubba Naidu (1 anna 4 pies but shown 2 1/2).

anchor.surface_text: Learned Attorney-General, appearing for the Revenue, company- tended that as the partnership deed did number specify the companyrect shares of Guruswamy Naidu and Venkatasubba Naidu in that while they were entitled only to 2 annas and 1 anna 4 pies share in accordance with the partition deed, they were shown in the partnership deed as holding 71 annas and 2 1/2 annas shares respectively

facts.text: Court held partnership genuine and shares in deed correct qua partnership.

anchor.surface_text: As the partnership deed was genuine, it must be held that the shares given to Guruswamy Naidu and Venkatasubba Naidu in the said partnership are companyrect in accordance with the terms of the partnership deed.

facts.text: High Court gave correct answers to questions.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons, we hold that the High Court has given companyrect answers to the question propounded. In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: A partner may be the karta of a joint Hindu family he may be a trustee he may enter into a sub-partnership with others he may, under an agreement, express or implied. be the representative of a group of persons he may be a benamidar for another. In all such cases he occupies a dual position. Qua the partnership he functions in his personal capacity qua the third parties, in his representative capacity.

concepts.interpretation: Partner acts personally qua partnership, representatively qua third parties; does not affect partnership validity or shares inter se

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: partition in the joint Hindu family allotting specific shares to the members of the family might have affected the accountability of the two partners

anchor.surface_text: The fact of a partition in the Hindu law may have no effect upon the position of the partner, insofar as the law of partnership is concerned, but it has full effect upon the family insofar as the Hindu law is concerned. Just as the fact of a karta becoming a partner does not introduce the members of the undivided family into the partnership, the division of the family does not change the position of the partner vis-a-vis the other partner or partners.

concepts.interpretation: Partition in family affects internal family accountability but not partners' shares or relations in partnership

issues.text: Whether the partnership deed specified the correct shares of the partners for registration under s. 26A notwithstanding the shares allotted under the family partition deed.

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal rightly held that the said partnership could not be registered under s. 26A of the Act. Mr. Swaminathan, learned counsel for the respondent contended that the partition of the familys beneficial interest in the partnership business has no relevance

issues.text: Whether the firm is genuine and valid so as to be entitled to registration under s. 26A of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We have held in The Commissioner of Income-tax, Ahmedabad v. M s. A. Abdul Rahim Co., Baroda 1  that the Income-tax Officer can reject the registration of a firm if it is not genuine or valid and if. the application for registration has not complied with the rules made under the Act. Here we have admittedly a genuine partnership.

arguments.claim: Partnership deed did not specify correct shares of Guruswamy Naidu (entitled to 2 annas per partition but shown 7 1/2) and Venkatasubba Naidu (1 anna 4 pies but shown 2 1/2), so could not be registered under s. 26A

anchor.surface_text: Learned Attorney-General, appearing for the Revenue, con- tended that as the partnership deed did not specify the cor- rect shares of Guruswamy Naidu and Venkatasubba Naidu in that while they were entitled only to 2 annas and 1 anna 4 pies share in accordance with the partition deed, they were shown in the partnership deed as holding 71 annas and 2 1/2 annas shares respectively and, therefore, the Tribunal rightly held that the said partnership could not be registered under s. 26A of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ecision of the Tribunal, the Commissioner of Income-tax acting under s. 33B of the Act cancelled the registration of the partnership on the ground tha

arguments.court_reasoning: Shares correct qua partnership as per deed terms; partition irrelevant to partnership relations

arguments.claim: Partition of family's beneficial interest has no relevance to registration under the Act; authorities concerned only with validity and genuineness of partnership deed, not partners' dealings with third parties

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Swaminathan, learned counsel for the respondent con- tended that the partition of the familys beneficial interest in the Sup./65- 3 partnership business has no relevance to the question of registration of the partnership under the Act, for, according to him, the authorities are only concerned with the validity and genuineness of the partnership deed executed by the partners thereof and not with the dealings of any one of the partners in respect of his share with third parties.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ecision of the Tribunal, the Commissioner of Income-tax acting under s. 33B of the Act cancelled the registration of the partnership on the ground tha

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; partnership law separate from Hindu family law; shares per deed govern registration

arguments.claim: Income-tax Officer can reject registration if firm not genuine or valid or application not complied with rules under the Act

anchor.surface_text: We have held in The Commissioner of Income-tax, Ahmedabad v. M s. A. Abdul Rahim Co., Baroda 1  that the Income-tax Officer can reject the registration of a firm if it is not genuine or valid and if. the application for registration has not complied with the rules made under the Act. Here we have admittedly a genuine partnership.

arguments.claim: Partnership is a creature of contract regulating rights and liabilities inter se partners; no concern with partners' obligations to others re shares

anchor.surface_text: If the distinction between three concepts is borne in mind much of the confusion disappears. A partnership is a creature of contract. Under Hindu law a joint family is one of status and right to partition is one of its incidents.

arguments.claim: Partner functions in personal capacity qua partnership, representative capacity qua third parties; does not affect partnership validity or shares

anchor.surface_text: A partner may be the karta of a joint Hindu family he may be a trustee he may enter into a sub-partnership with others he may, under an agreement, express or implied. be the representative of a group of persons he may be a benamidar for another. In all such cases he occupies a dual position. Qua the partnership he functions in his personal capacity qua the third parties, in his representative capacity.

arguments.claim: Guruswamy Naidu could validly take 10 annas share in partnership despite only 2 annas per family partition; answerable to family but partnership unaffected

anchor.surface_text: If that be so, Guruswamy Naidu could have validly entered into a genuine partnership with others taking a 10 annas share in the business, though in fact as between the members of the family he has only a 2 annas share therein. He would have been answerable for the profits per-  1 1965 2 S.C.R. 12. taining to his share to the divided members of the family, but it would not have affected the validity or genuineness of the partnership.

arguments.claim: Partition has no effect on partner's position qua partnership law, though full effect under Hindu law; karta partnership doesn't introduce family members

anchor.surface_text: The fact of a partition in the Hindu law may have no effect upon the position of the partner, insofar as the law of partnership is concerned, but it has full effect upon the family insofar as the Hindu law is concerned. Just as the fact of a karta becoming a partner does not introduce the members of the undivided family into the partnership, the division of the family does not change the position of the partner vis-a-vis the other partner or partners.

arguments.claim: Partnership genuine; partition affects only accountability to family members, not relationship qua partnership with other partners

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the Madras High Court, which heard the reference, came to the conclusion that the partnership was a genuine one, that the partition in the joint Hindu family allotting specific shares to the members of the family might have affected the accountability of the two partners of the firm to the other members of the family, but qua the partnership their relationship with the other partners had not in any way been affected and, therefore, the Tribunal went wrong in holding that the registration of the said partnership was rightly refused.

holdings.text: The High Court has given correct answers to the questions propounded.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons, we hold that the High Court has given correct answers to the question propounded. In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partnership deed governs correct shares qua partnership; family partition irrelevant to registration under s.26A; supports affirming High Court on both referred questions.

holdings.text: As the partnership deed was genuine, the shares given to Guruswamy Naidu and Venkatasubba Naidu in the said partnership are correct in accordance with the terms of the partnership deed.

anchor.surface_text: As the partnership deed was genuine, it must be held that the shares given to Guruswamy Naidu and Venkatasubba Naidu in the said partnership are correct in accordance with the terms of the partnership deed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Shares per partnership deed valid inter se partners regardless of internal family partition entitlements; dual capacity of partners (personal qua firm, representative qua family).

holdings.text: The Income-tax Officer can reject the registration of a firm if it is not genuine or valid and if the application for registration has not complied with the rules made under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We have held in The Commissioner of Income-tax, Ahmedabad v. M s. A. Abdul Rahim Co., Baroda 1  that the Income-tax Officer can reject the registration of a firm if it is not genuine or valid and if. the application for registration has not complied with the rules made under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying prior Supreme Court precedent; here partnership genuine and valid, rules complied as deed shows correct inter se shares.

holdings.text: The division of the family does not change the position of the partner vis-a-vis the other partner or partners.

anchor.surface_text: Just as the fact of a karta becoming a partner does not introduce the members of the undivided family into the partnership, the division of the family does not change the position of the partner vis-a-vis the other partner or partners.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hindu law partition affects family relations but not partnership law relations; supported by Charandas Haridas precedent.

holdings.text: Here we have admittedly a genuine partnership. It cannot even be suggested that it is invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No challenge to genuineness or validity; objection solely on share mismatch with partition dismissed as irrelevant.

precedents.citation: Charandas Haridas v. Commissioner of Income- tax, Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Charandas Haridas v. Commissioner of Income- tax, Bombay 1  had to companysider a companyverse position. There a karta of a Hindu undivided family was a partner in 6 managing agency firms and the share of the managing agency companymission received by him as such partner being assessed as the income of the family.

precedents.case_name: Charandas Haridas v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: partition in Hindu family does not affect the position of the partner qua partnership; law of partnership and Hindu law operate in different fields; observations support that divided members can enter partnership with shares per partnership deed
precedents.cited_holding: as the partition document was a genuine one, it was fully effective between the members of the family and therefore the income in respect of the divided property was not the income of the Hindu joint family

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

outcome.relief_summary: The appeals by the Revenue fail and are dismissed, upholding High Court order that cancellation of registration was unlawful and firm is registrable under s. 26A.
